segments.text: The courses, like statistics, were important because it's the foundation on which what we call forest maturation is built.
And soils and economics, plant physiology,
Those sorts of things were key, and those were courses that were taken outside the department.
But you end up in forestry having about four or five what we call core courses.
One of them is, well, ecology would be another external course.
But if you have about four or five core courses, then that includes silviculture, mensuration, management,
whatever you call your wood technology course, and forest economics.
If you had all of the faculty members from those years, both in required courses in the department and outside the department, and they were all lined up, which ones would you want to thank most?
Well, there were two people that were here when I came.
Bob Rhodes, who was a...
totally devoted person to students.
I mean, there was a stream of students coming in his office all the time.
And he served a valuable role because he taught dendrology and those kind of courses, ecology and those kind of courses.
But certainly, he played a major role.
Dave Mooring.
would be the other one that I would identify.
He just spent an inordinate amount of time
carried a heavy research load, but spent an inordinate amount of time with students.
And he'd haul those kids to East Texas, you know, all for, you know, come back in the middle of the night and this sort of thing.
And I was really devoted to him.
In fact,
When he left us with the Mississippi State in a few years, he was on their school forest and had a heart attack.
Were there some people teaching courses outside the department that did an excellent job?
Yeah, your chemistry, biology, economics.
All right, what about the advising and the counseling?
Who are the people that undergraduates in forest science would turn to?
Well, Roach.
What about at the college level?
I guess Dick Pops was over there one day.
But that's who they talked to.
Do you have any good student anecdotes to share?
Serious or not so serious as far as science and student stories?
Well, a lot of those sort of things come out of either field trips
or our summer camp.
We have a summer program where we take them to East Texas for a period of weeks and keep them there.
and do a lot of the field work that is related to the theory that they get in their courses over here.
And they live, we've had them over at Huntsville at San Houston Dorm.
We've had them out on the San Houston National Forest
I think it was an old job course center.
And right now, they share the East Texas Conservation Center that Stephen F. Austin owns over on Lake Sam Rayburn.
But anyway, they live in an outdoor, fairly rudimentary situation.
And those are always...
fertile ground for problems and interesting stories.
I do recall one time when one of our, when we were finishing up the summer camp, it was the last day and we had a big
and so on down in front of the lakes on St. Houston National Forest.
And there was a fair amount of beer drinking going on, and everybody got thrown in the lake, including all the faculty.
And after we got through this, one of the students said, I lost my ID risk.
And so we, it was pitch dark then.
We kind of looked around a little bit and couldn't find it.
And the next day, he came out there.
He and some others came out and started looking around the edge of the lake there.
And then...
was sitting there in about six inches of water, I guess, at least enough to where it was clearly visible.
And you talk about one happy son.
He was really pleased.
Another Aggie Ring story.
We had, A&M had a big contract
which you probably remember with the Dominican Republic.
And it involved several things, but one of them was to bring students up here and give them degrees.
We had, I don't know, four or five Dominican students in forestry.
And they did okay and got out.
and went back to the Dominican.
And Owens, Illinois had an operation down there in the Dominican.
And one of them went to work for Owens, Illinois.
And anyway, somewhere in the woods of the Dominican, he lost his baggy ring.
So the vice president for Owens, Illinois,
operation, called me up one day and says, how do you get an Aggie ring?
I said, well, it takes about four years.
He said, no.
He said, then he told me the story.
I can't think of his kid's name now.
I think he had something like that.
he's a lot
Did you feel that you all were given, compared to the other departments in agriculture, were you all given equitable treatment?
Well, you'll never get a department head to admit that.
That's what I thought.
Whose budget do you wish you could have had, and which departments?
Well, just let me name the department heads.
And then you, O.D.
Butler, Perry Atkinson, entomology, Ty Timm, ag economics.
Those guys always seem to do well.
The other one that did well was
was Morris Bloodworth.
He was .
I'd say those four probably prospered during my period as department head.
Then when I went over to the experiment station, and Neville Clark showed up over there, and we started looking at the books, we found out why.
They basically put together two budgets.
I don't know that Ty Pinn was, I think Ty was already out of the picture by then, but anyway.
But certainly Perry and O.D.
and Morris.
And then Jarvis would, you know, pay the budgets, they'd go through the board and the whole bit.
They'd come back over and out.
Jarvis, here's our real budget.
So I found out that all department heads were not created equal.
During those days, you, as department head, you were not the chairman.
You were the head.
Did you all, in those days, in that department, were salaries and promotions on a percentage basis, or were they all on a merit basis?
Well, they were all on a, for the most part, unless we got told that everybody gets 3% or 5% or whatever, they were on a merit basis.
But in those days also, you will recall that the department head was lowered.
Faculty governments didn't exist.
So whatever I felt like those guys deserved, promotions were a bit different because that was another more
and then you have to go defend them without mentioning any significant pain do you remember during that period any situation where you lost somebody because
Another school just outbid them and took somebody away that you wanted to keep.
I'd say Goldstein, and more in chief probably, but they offered Goldstein as the head of the big department of NC State, so that was a bit of a different deal.
Others that we lost of that early group, I don't recall.
And we made some counteroffers in the United States.
You mentioned faculty government and so forth.
Based on your experience of more than three decades, if you were the dictator and didn't have to explain it to any committee or any voters,

What role would you have the faculty play in a department today that wants to make real progress in terms of what role would the faculty play in salary increases and so forth and evaluation of the capability of faculty?
I think the faculty.
principle and probably the most important role is in the promotion and tenure process.
I think that's clear that their involvement there is important to maintaining standards and this sort of thing.
I'm not convinced that
resource allocation is something that they do very well.
There's always a greed factor there that creeps into almost anything you do like that.
Most recently, when I was interim department head for about 18 months over there, we had some funds that were centrally held and could be allocated for graduate programs, for teaching equipment.
Previous department head had a committee of faculty to do that, and I thought that was fine.
I thought that was the best way.
There wasn't a whole lot of money involved, but it was still fun.
But routine resource allocation, take input wherever you can get it,
But there is a process that we have that
is probably not practiced as religiously as it should be, and that's performance appraisal.
And if you do a good job of performance appraisal, and the faculty are responsive to that, I mean, they commit themselves to that, then I think you get a pretty good reading on it.
And it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out who the,
achievers are and who are not.
Of course, you run into a problem where you have a high achiever who's a son of a bitch.
And that's just a very frustrating thing to deal with.
But there are those people who are that way.
And in a few instances, you have somebody who is extremely convenient, extremely pleasant, always glad-handed, but not very productive enough.
And then one of my frustrations with some faculty committees is that they don't assume enough responsibility for the results of their decisions.
for example, a search committee that hires some key person, they then walk away.
Right.
And somebody else is responsible to leave with the consequences of that force.
All right.
So let's make believe there are 40 to 50 forestry programs.
And 30 years ago, A&M was a beginner.
in that 40-50, just getting started.
At the time you moved away from the department headship, where would you have placed A&M in that 40-50, in the top or bottom, divided into some kind of percentiles?
Oh, I would say we were around the middle of somewhere.
We went up, though, in a few years and probably peaked when Charles Lee was head of the department.
He was a very good department.
We recruited him from Mississippi State.
Did he follow you?
Well, no, there was a guy between us who was a loser, and so we lost the road.
Where did Lee come from?
He came in the early 80s.
I left in 77, and then we had this guy in Penn State that came for about three or four years, and he just didn't work out.
But when Charlie came, that department flourished.
And he probably stayed there until, oh, 1988 or 89, somewhere along in there.
And during that period of time, the department was probably in the top 25%.
No, they've lost Graham.
And again, there's been a lot of slippage in keeping the department head position moving.
You get a guy in there that the administration
doesn't feel good about, and the department starts to slip, and he senses that, and faculty begins to sense, and then finally they decide to do something about it.
Well, you know, that's several years, and then there's a long, you know, go find somebody else.
There's a good department head in there now.
He's kind of new to the game, but he's going to be super.
And I see the department coming back.
In a theoretically perfect arrangement, would a department head be hired with a specific term, four-year, five-year, renewable?
Well, I think that's the case now.
They get a two-year review from there, and then a four-year review that's more comprehensive, and then another four-year review.
Most of the department heads in agriculture
tend to make careers out of being department heads.
That's not quite so much the case now as it was 20 years ago.
But look at OD and so on.
So the review process is important.
But more important than that is some sort of timely action.
timely action if there's a problem.
Because the department can slip so bad.
I've wondered also, what is your opinion about this?
Most departments, when they lose through retirement, death, or going somewhere else, the top-notch senior person tend to fill that with a junior person, a beginner.
Is that good to do that normally?
Does that keep the prestige of the department high?
Or should they try on occasion to hire a top-notch senior person?
Well, I think it's certainly, from the department perspective, it's good to go get
if that's an area that you want to continue to emphasize to get a good person and a senior person in that position.
But what's happening now is you get so much salary erosion that you can't afford to go higher.
a good person because you know what it takes to go out on the market these days and try to hire somebody, a senior person.
And most departments can't afford to do that.
I've talked to the way the big, old, high-level schools, the old projects, they've got million-dollar positions
institution in that specialty.
And we, as public schools, don't do that as well.
But because of, and again, you mentioned the funding issue.
I found in some cases, the faculty in the department thinks, oh, if this person who left is making a big salary, if we fill it with a person with a mighty salary, we'll get to keep that difference.
So we told them, no.
All right.
You go over to the experiment station after eight years.
What attracted you there?
Well, it was kind of a false attraction.
The department heads in brain science and wildlife and fisheries and recreation and parks and forestry had been plotting
since I came to form a school of that nature.
And there's precedent for that all over the West.
And so we had made a proposal to do that.
And Jack Williams, when it got to his desk, says, coordinating board's not entertaining any
new organizational units at this time.
Let's run this up a flagpole.
So John Calhoun sent a letter back to Harry and said, in fact Jack said, why don't you do something we can do internally?
to identify this group of departments the way they want the identity.
And so the idea was to form an institute of renewable natural resources.
That's what we did.
And then I was going to go over and be the director of it.
Well, about the time I headed over there,
Jarvis moved to the president's office.
Neville Carr came in as director of the Experiment Station.
And I literally got submerged in the Experiment Station business.
And was never really able to lift the Institute out of the
organizational mire.
And that's been going on ever since.
And that's still a topic of discussion.
I saw it on the agenda of a meeting that we had here in the Ag Program Conference a couple of weeks ago.
And Bob Brown, who's head of Wildlife and Fisheries now, was sort of a daddy rabbit to try to do something about that.
So that's the reason I went over there, but it never materialized.
Right.
And your title when you go to the conversation was what?
Associate Director.
Associate Director.
And you served in the Associate Director of?
For about...
Describe your duties.
Well, I primarily, I had some budget responsibilities.
Facilities were almost all mine.
Programatically, Neville and I sort of
We did that together with the part of the agency that served him.
The building behind him, he stayed on the road for a great deal.
He was very active in that way.
and built in behind him .
But budget and facilities and programs, I guess, were my primary activities.
During those 11 years, give some examples of some of the big decisions you remember.
Well, I think probably the most significant thing that we did was make a major run at the legislature in 1983 for a substantial amount of money across probably six or eight different programs.
One of them was called Biotechnology Factory.
And we were successful, almost totally successful.
And with that, those resources, and that was about the last year we had with the legislature, because you remember in 85, oil had gone south.
And it was, you know, Mark White was
whacking at us and so it was pretty tough sledding going on.
So we got in on the last good year.

But that money was put together in a central pool and used as a competitive grants program for people in the extermination station to start building programs in six or eight areas that we had identified.
And certainly
where we are now with molecular biology is largely due to that state investment.
that was made, which was about $2 million in the biotechnology program.
And we recruited Gene Sander then for biochemistry and some new hires there.
We made the decision that we would not create a central biotechnology center like a lot of universities
